title: How to Model Bullets in 3DS Max

steps.headline: Use a reference image.
steps.description: This is required for modelling. Go to the web and download an image showing the schematic of a bullet with its case.

steps.headline: Check the dimensions of your reference image.
steps.description: Right click on the reference image. Then, click properties and go to the details tab.

steps.headline: Start 3DS Max.
Change your view to Perspective for easy editing.
steps.description: Click on the bottom right window, then press Alt + W on keyboard to maximize your perspective view..

steps.headline: Change the unit setup in 3DS Max.
steps.description:
Go to Customize > Units Setup. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c9\/6.-Click-customize.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c9\/6.-Click-customize.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":515,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":850.4180064308682,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Change the Display Unit Scale to Metric and choose "millimeters" from drop down. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/f\/f2\/7.-Change-units.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/f\/f2\/7.-Change-units.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":624,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1030.5501618122978,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Create a plane.
Modify the length and width of your plane from the modify panel.
steps.description: Divide your reference image length and width pixel count by 10 (eg: 506 pixels will be 50.6mm) and change the length and width parameters of plane in mm. This will allow you to use the image without altering the aspect ratio of the picture.

steps.headline: Open the compact material panel.
steps.description:
Click rendering in toolbar. Click material editor and choose Compact material editor. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b7\/8.-open-material-editor.png\/460px-8.-open-material-editor.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b7\/8.-open-material-editor.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":647,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1069.3467336683418,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Add your reference image to the plane.
Apply the image to your plane.
Align the plane to start modeling.
Add a new cylinder for bullet casing.
steps.description:
Go to the "Create" tab. Click on cylinder in standard primitives. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d6\/12.-Create-Cyl.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d6\/12.-Create-Cyl.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":780,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1289.3532338308457,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click and drag in the viewport. Center it on the x, y & z axis. Do not worry about its dimensions.

steps.headline: Change view to aid your modeling.
steps.description:
Click on the "Perspective" tab at top left of viewport. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/50\/14.-left-view.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/50\/14.-left-view.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":536,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":886.3427109974425,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Select Left view in the drop down menu.

steps.headline: Turn the cylinder transparent to allow us to see our image.
steps.description:
Click on Edit in the toolbar. Click Object Properties and wait for window to open. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/54\/16.-Object-prop.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/54\/16.-Object-prop.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":874,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1444,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Select the "See through" option in display properties and then click OK.{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/2\/27\/17.-see-through.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/2\/27\/17.-see-through.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":661,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1091.4893617021276,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Position your cylinder.
steps.description:
Select "Move tool" from toolbar (keyboard shortcut W). {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e6\/18.-Move-tool.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e6\/18.-Move-tool.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":216,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":356.1716171617162,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Align the bottom of cylinder with the bottom of bullet in reference image. Align the cylinder center axis with the center axis of bullet in reference image.

steps.headline: Change dimensions of cylinder roughly to size of bullet casing.
steps.description:
Go to Modify panel. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/70\/20.-Modifier-panel.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/70\/20.-Modifier-panel.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":273,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":450.6194690265487,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Match height and radius of the cylinder to the bullet casing of reference image. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bf\/19.-Cyl-para-to-img.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bf\/19.-Cyl-para-to-img.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":679,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1121.711229946524,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Add Edit poly modifier.
steps.description:
Click modifier list from the modifier panel. Select "Edit poly" from the drop down menu. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/21.-add-edit-poly.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/21.-add-edit-poly.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":832,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1375.2380952380952,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Extrude the vertices to add more height.
Create bullet case bottom notch.
Extrude Top border to create thickness.
steps.description:
Click the face select tool. Select, then delete the top face of cylinder. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/27.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/460px-27.-Delete-top-face.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/27.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/760px-27.-Delete-top-face.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click the border select tool. Select the topmost border. Extrude the border about -5mm. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f0\/28.-Top-Edge-and-neg-extrude.jpg\/460px-28.-Top-Edge-and-neg-extrude.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f0\/28.-Top-Edge-and-neg-extrude.jpg\/760px-28.-Top-Edge-and-neg-extrude.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Add a new cylinder for the bullet.
steps.description: This cylinder will be the actual bullet. Go to "Create" tab. Click on cylinder in standard primitives, then click and drag in the viewport.

steps.headline: Adjust the dimensions of the second cylinder.
steps.description: Position it to the bullet in the reference image.

steps.headline: Adjust the radius to be smaller than the first cylinder.
steps.description: Don't let it be too small to leave a visible gap in between the two cylinders.

steps.headline: Add Edit Poly modifier to the cylinder.
Model the shape of bullet.
steps.description:
Add more loops at the top of the cylinder. Click on Modeling panel in toolbar. Click Edit>Swiftloop. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/30.-Swift-Loop.jpg\/460px-30.-Swift-Loop.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/30.-Swift-Loop.jpg\/760px-30.-Swift-Loop.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add up to 4 cuts at the top half of the cylinder. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/31.-Create-cuts.jpg\/460px-31.-Create-cuts.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/31.-Create-cuts.jpg\/760px-31.-Create-cuts.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Create a round dome shape.
steps.description:
Click on vertices select tool. Select all the newly created vertices along with the top vertices. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/10\/32..jpg\/460px-32..jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/10\/32..jpg\/760px-32..jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Scale the ring of vertices to smaller size on the xy axis. De-select the bottom most ring. Scale it down again on the xy axis. Repeat scaling two more times and de-select one ring of vertices from bottom every time you scale down to give it a crude, dome like shape. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/33.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/460px-33.-Delete-top-face.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/33.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/760px-33.-Delete-top-face.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Model the bullet point.
Remove the see-through option from both the cylinders.
Add Loops to edges of the case.
Smooth the case.
steps.description: Click on the modifier list from the modifier panel. Select and add "Turbosmooth" from the drop down menu.

tyn: Reference image of a bullet showing schematic.
3DS Max or similar 3D software installed in your system.
sentences: Set up your Work Use a reference image.
This is required for modelling.
Go to the web and download an image showing the schematic of a bullet with its case.
Check the dimensions of your reference image.
Right click on the reference image.
Then, click properties and go to the details tab.
Start 3DS Max.
Change your view to Perspective for easy editing.
Click on the bottom right window, then press Alt + W on keyboard to maximize your perspective view.. Change the unit setup in 3DS Max.
Go to Customize > Units Setup.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c9\/6.-Click-customize.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c9\/6.-Click-customize.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":515,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":850.4180064308682,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Change the Display Unit Scale to Metric and choose "millimeters" from drop down.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/f\/f2\/7.-Change-units.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/f\/f2\/7.-Change-units.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":624,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1030.5501618122978,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Create a plane.
Go to the "Create" tab, then click on "plane" in standard primitives.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bd\/2.-create-plane.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bd\/2.-create-plane.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":622,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1027.5510204081634,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click and drag in the viewport, then center it in x, y & z axis.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3b\/6.-Center-the-plane.jpg\/460px-6.-Center-the-plane.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3b\/6.-Center-the-plane.jpg\/760px-6.-Center-the-plane.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Right click on the up-down arrows in the x, y & z field to position the plane at zero.
Modify the length and width of your plane from the modify panel.
Divide your reference image length and width pixel count by 10 (eg: 506 pixels will be 50.6mm) and change the length and width parameters of plane in mm.
This will allow you to use the image without altering the aspect ratio of the picture.
Open the compact material panel.
Click rendering in toolbar.
Click material editor and choose Compact material editor.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b7\/8.-open-material-editor.png\/460px-8.-open-material-editor.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b7\/8.-open-material-editor.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":647,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1069.3467336683418,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add your reference image to the plane.
Click on the empty field near diffuse color.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/6\/65\/9.-Choose-diffuse.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/6\/65\/9.-Choose-diffuse.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":282,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":465.39325842696627,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click the "+" on General to open options in the Material/Map Browser.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/22\/10.-Click-General.png\/460px-10.-Click-General.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/2\/22\/10.-Click-General.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":163,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":269.45454545454544,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Double click on bitmap.
Wait for material browser to open.
Navigate to the folder and double click your reference image.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/84\/9.-Select-Image.jpg\/460px-9.-Select-Image.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/84\/9.-Select-Image.jpg\/760px-9.-Select-Image.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Apply the image to your plane.
Click on Assign material to selection.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/a\/a7\/11.-assign-material.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/a\/a7\/11.-assign-material.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":192,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":316.5133171912833,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click on Show shaded material in viewport.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/00\/11.-show-material.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/00\/11.-show-material.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":192,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":316.5133171912833,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Interchange length and width of the plane, if the image gets stretched as shown above.
Align the plane to start modeling.
Select rotate tool (keyboard shortcut R).
Select angle snap to rotate in 5 degree increments for ease (keyboard shortcut A).
Rotate 90 degrees on the z-axis.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/31\/12.-Rotate.jpg\/460px-12.-Rotate.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/31\/12.-Rotate.jpg\/760px-12.-Rotate.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Rotate 90 degrees on y-axis.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/13.-Rotate-again.jpg\/460px-13.-Rotate-again.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/13.-Rotate-again.jpg\/760px-13.-Rotate-again.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Select move tool (keyboard shortcut W), then move the plane back on its x-axis.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/26\/14.-Push-back.jpg\/460px-14.-Push-back.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/26\/14.-Push-back.jpg\/760px-14.-Push-back.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Start modelling the Bullet Case Add a new cylinder for bullet casing.
Go to the "Create" tab.
Click on cylinder in standard primitives.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d6\/12.-Create-Cyl.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d6\/12.-Create-Cyl.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":780,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1289.3532338308457,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click and drag in the viewport.
Center it on the x, y & z axis.
Do not worry about its dimensions.
Change view to aid your modeling.
Click on the "Perspective" tab at top left of viewport.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/50\/14.-left-view.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/50\/14.-left-view.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":536,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":886.3427109974425,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Select Left view in the drop down menu.
Turn the cylinder transparent to allow us to see our image.
Click on Edit in the toolbar.
Click Object Properties and wait for window to open.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/54\/16.-Object-prop.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/54\/16.-Object-prop.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":874,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1444,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Select the "See through" option in display properties and then click OK.{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/2\/27\/17.-see-through.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/2\/27\/17.-see-through.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":661,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1091.4893617021276,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Position your cylinder.
Select "Move tool" from toolbar (keyboard shortcut W).

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e6\/18.-Move-tool.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e6\/18.-Move-tool.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":216,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":356.1716171617162,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Align the bottom of cylinder with the bottom of bullet in reference image.
Align the cylinder center axis with the center axis of bullet in reference image.
Change dimensions of cylinder roughly to size of bullet casing.
Go to Modify panel.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/70\/20.-Modifier-panel.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/70\/20.-Modifier-panel.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":273,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":450.6194690265487,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Match height and radius of the cylinder to the bullet casing of reference image.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bf\/19.-Cyl-para-to-img.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bf\/19.-Cyl-para-to-img.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":679,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1121.711229946524,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add Edit poly modifier.
Click modifier list from the modifier panel.
Select "Edit poly" from the drop down menu.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/21.-add-edit-poly.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/21.-add-edit-poly.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":832,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1375.2380952380952,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Extrude the vertices to add more height.
Click on vertex button from edit poly modifier.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/de\/24.-Select-vertex.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/de\/24.-Select-vertex.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":138,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":228.3743842364532,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click and drag to select all the top vertices of the cylinder.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/47\/21.-Select-top-vertices.jpg\/460px-21.-Select-top-vertices.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/47\/21.-Select-top-vertices.jpg\/760px-21.-Select-top-vertices.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click on the small button next to extrude.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/4b\/23.-Extrude-setting.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/4b\/23.-Extrude-setting.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":571.1242603550296,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Extrude the vertices using setting box opened.
Do twice since the bullet casing has two bends at the top.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/6\/62\/25.-Extrude-sett.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/6\/62\/25.-Extrude-sett.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":552,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":912,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Create bullet case bottom notch.
Select all the bottom vertices.
Align the selected vertices to top part of the notch, on the z axis, as shown below with the reference image.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/57\/23.-Extrude-for-bottom.jpg\/460px-23.-Extrude-for-bottom.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/57\/23.-Extrude-for-bottom.jpg\/760px-23.-Extrude-for-bottom.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Extrude again.
Do it twice exactly to match the edges for the notch.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b2\/24.-Extrude-twice.jpg\/460px-24.-Extrude-twice.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b2\/24.-Extrude-twice.jpg\/760px-24.-Extrude-twice.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click on faces button in modifier panel.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b3\/26.-select-faces.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b3\/26.-select-faces.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":176,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":290.4712041884817,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Then select the ring of faces (one up from bottom) as shown in the picture.
Extrude the faces negatively.
In this image below a value of -5mm is used.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a0\/25.-Select-face-and-negative-extrude.jpg\/460px-25.-Select-face-and-negative-extrude.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a0\/25.-Select-face-and-negative-extrude.jpg\/760px-25.-Select-face-and-negative-extrude.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Select bottom most ring of faces.
Scale them on xy axis by clicking on the select & uniform scale in toolbar (keyboard shortcut R).
Hover mouse on xy plane of the pivot as shown in the figure.
Then click and drag to scale.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ec\/26.-Scale-bottom.jpg\/460px-26.-Scale-bottom.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ec\/26.-Scale-bottom.jpg\/760px-26.-Scale-bottom.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Extrude Top border to create thickness.
Click the face select tool.
Select, then delete the top face of cylinder.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/27.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/460px-27.-Delete-top-face.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/27.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/760px-27.-Delete-top-face.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click the border select tool.
Select the topmost border.
Extrude the border about -5mm.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f0\/28.-Top-Edge-and-neg-extrude.jpg\/460px-28.-Top-Edge-and-neg-extrude.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f0\/28.-Top-Edge-and-neg-extrude.jpg\/760px-28.-Top-Edge-and-neg-extrude.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Model the Bullet Add a new cylinder for the bullet.
This cylinder will be the actual bullet.
Go to "Create" tab.
Click on cylinder in standard primitives, then click and drag in the viewport.
Adjust the dimensions of the second cylinder.
Position it to the bullet in the reference image.
Adjust the radius to be smaller than the first cylinder.
Don't let it be too small to leave a visible gap in between the two cylinders.
Add Edit Poly modifier to the cylinder.
Go to Modify panel, then click on the modifier list.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/70\/20.-Modifier-panel.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/70\/20.-Modifier-panel.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":273,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":450.6194690265487,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Select "Edit poly" from the drop down menu.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/21.-add-edit-poly.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/21.-add-edit-poly.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":832,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1375.2380952380952,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Then repeat step 3 in Part 2 for see through.
Model the shape of bullet.
Add more loops at the top of the cylinder.
Click on Modeling panel in toolbar.
Click Edit>Swiftloop.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/30.-Swift-Loop.jpg\/460px-30.-Swift-Loop.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/30.-Swift-Loop.jpg\/760px-30.-Swift-Loop.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add up to 4 cuts at the top half of the cylinder.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/31.-Create-cuts.jpg\/460px-31.-Create-cuts.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/31.-Create-cuts.jpg\/760px-31.-Create-cuts.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Create a round dome shape.
Click on vertices select tool.
Select all the newly created vertices along with the top vertices.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/10\/32..jpg\/460px-32..jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/10\/32..jpg\/760px-32..jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Scale the ring of vertices to smaller size on the xy axis.
De-select the bottom most ring.
Scale it down again on the xy axis.
Repeat scaling two more times and de-select one ring of vertices from bottom every time you scale down to give it a crude, dome like shape.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/33.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/460px-33.-Delete-top-face.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/33.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/760px-33.-Delete-top-face.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Model the bullet point.
Click on face select tool.
Select the top face of bullet.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/33.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/460px-33.-Delete-top-face.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/33.-Delete-top-face.jpg\/760px-33.-Delete-top-face.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Delete the top face.
Select all the top vertices.
Do a negative extrude as much as possible with a very small gap.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/34.-Neg-extr.jpg\/460px-34.-Neg-extr.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/34.-Neg-extr.jpg\/760px-34.-Neg-extr.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click on the Weld tool in modifiers panel.
Weld all these extruded top vertices.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c2\/35.-Weld.jpg\/460px-35.-Weld.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c2\/35.-Weld.jpg\/760px-35.-Weld.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Select and pull the new welded vertice to the top using the move tool.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/86\/36.-Pull-upward.jpg\/460px-36.-Pull-upward.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/86\/36.-Pull-upward.jpg\/760px-36.-Pull-upward.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Click modifier list from the modifier panel.
Select and add "Turbosmooth" from the drop down menu.
This will give the bullet a smooth look.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c4\/37.-Turbo-smth-with-2-iter.jpg\/460px-37.-Turbo-smth-with-2-iter.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c4\/37.-Turbo-smth-with-2-iter.jpg\/760px-37.-Turbo-smth-with-2-iter.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add Finishing Touches Remove the see-through option from both the cylinders.
Add Loops to edges of the case.
Click on Modeling panel in toolbar.
Click Edit>Swiftloop.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/30.-Swift-Loop.jpg\/460px-30.-Swift-Loop.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/30.-Swift-Loop.jpg\/760px-30.-Swift-Loop.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":259,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":428.02197802197804,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add loop cuts at all the edges of the case notch and at the bottom.
Click on the modifier list from the modifier panel.
Select and add "Turbosmooth" from the drop down menu.
